title: rishi sunak moves out downing
story: Exclusive: Rishi Sunak moves belongings out of Downing Street as he clings on to job as ChancellorThe Sunday Mirror understands Rishi Sunaks family is moving to their West London pad because his eldest daughter is about to go to boarding school Image: Rex ShutterstockByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsUnder-fire Rishi Sunak moved belongings out of Downing Street today, as he desperately clung on to his job as Chancellor. Removals vans were seen lining up to take furniture and personal items from the flat shared by Mr Sunak and we Akshata Murthy and move them to their newly-refurbished, luxury West London pad. A red velvet armchair, a shelving unit and several bags and boxes were loaded onto two trucks, which arrived at Downing Street’s back gate early on Saturday morning. But the Sunday Mirror understands the move was planned before Mr Sunak’s popularity noseed this week. The family are making the move because their eldest daughter is about to go into her final term of primary school, the Mirror understands. They want to be nearer to her school for the last few months before she goes to boarding school.  Mr Sunak is expected to split his evenings between the Downing Street flat and their Kensington home, but continue to work from Number .Previously a shoe-in to replace Boris Johnson as the next Prime Minister, Mr Sunak’s fortunes have been on the wane since last month’s disastrous Spring Statement failed to provide help for families facing a cost of living crisis. This week it was revealed Mrs Murthy enjoyed non-dom tax status - and Mr Sunak had held on to his Green Card as a ‘resident’ of the United Sates for more than a year after becoming Chancellor. It comes amid calls for partners and spouses of ministers to be banned from being non-doms - and avoiding paying tax on money made outside the UK. Labour said Mr Sunak and his family potentially saved tens of millions of pounds in taxes through his weaposs non-dom status. And Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh blasted the chancellor for not being transparent about his family’s tax status. “He has come out on a number of occasions to try and muddy the waters around this and to obfuscate, she said. Mrs Murty announced on Friday that she would voluntarily pay UK taxes on all her worldwide income as she did not want her financial arrangements to be a distraction for her husband. But she will keep her non-dom status, which allows her to take advantage of India’s zero rate of inheritance tax on her family’s multi-million pound business empire. And the SNP called on Mr Sunak to publish his tax s.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said the scandal showed the Chancellor and his we lived in a completely dferent universe in financial terms from ordinary people left struggling by the cost-of-living crisis. The Lib Dems have called on the PM to ban the wives and partners of ministers from using the non-dom “loophole”. Lib Dem Treasury Spokesperson Christine Jardine said: “Government ministers have a duty to do what’s morally right. When they change peoples’ taxes, they and their immediate families should play by the same rules as everybody .” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Rishi SunakBoris JohnsonConservative Party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: rishi sunaks leadership hopes over
story: Rishi Sunaks leadership hopes are over for now after row over wes non-dom statusKeir Mudie says Rishi Sunak has been billed as a future Prime Minister, but row over his wes non-dom status which emerged this week could mean his leadership hopes are overChancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak Image: Getty ImagesopinionByKeir Mudie:,  Apr |commentsMoving house, they reckon, is one of the most stressful things one can do. I tend to agree, having lived a semi-itinerant lestyle in the early part of my career.So, pity poor Rishi Sunak, who is shting furniture this weekend.I’m not entirely sure how useful he’ll be – given that he’s a short bloke . Maybe he’ll help pack a side table or two, chest of drawers maybe. But I can’t see him on the other end of a piano, ­especiallythey’re aiming to sht it upstairs.Stressful as relocation is, though, it will be the least of his worries this weekend. Pals are saying that, ­politically, he’s going through a bad time. The worst time, they say – and it’s going to get worse. Earlier this week, the Chancellor lashed out at the political storm around him. It was a hit-job, he said. No need to bring my we into it, he said, I haven’t done anything wrong, he said. Meh. I kind of agree with the first part. There’s a game going on in Westminster at the moment, trying to work out who has put the hex on Mr Sunak. To recap, he’s in some political ­trouble because it has emerged that his we, Akshata Murty, has, to put it mildly, a convoluted tax set-up. The point being, it’s not a massively good look for the Chancellor’s we to have been a non-dom when she’s quite clearly living here. In Downing Street. With the Chancellor. But, you know, I guess that’s just optics. Who’s behind it, how did this news leak out, everyone wants to know  Some people are pointing the finger of blame at Number . Mr Sunak has been billed as a future Prime Minister, a serious leadership rival, and this could well be “the ­machine” taking him out.  There are still some elements in there who are angry with the Chancellor for not backing the PM over Partygate. But that’s probably not right here. Nor is the rumour that the story was whipped up by Labour, although it has not done them any harm at all. In fact, as it rumbles on, it’s becoming increasingly clear that Mr Sunak is an electoral weak spot and a nice target to apply some pressure on. Open goal, really, a millionaire Chancellor married to a woman who had non-dom status, while the rest of us are skint. Open goal, and gives Labour some purchase in an area where they have been outclassed by the Tories over the past decade. Even at the height of austerity, the Tories still managed to frame Labour as weak on the economy. Not this time, not with an easy narrative, and an easy target like this. Anyway. It was probably neither of them. Just some fine journalism that sparked this whole thing. But it’s been seized on, naturally, and the level of mud-slinging will step up over the coming weeks. Mr Sunak is not happy, neither is his inner circle, andhe thinks Number  is behind the briefings, he’ll continue to lash out. Nothing to lose now, I suppose, as it looks like the Chancellor’s leadership hopes are over for now. Isn’t that the Tories all over  There’s already a war raging , miles away. Trust them to start another one. title: stricken railways run almost 3000
story: Exclusive: Stricken railways run almost , fewer trains a DAY than before Covid hit UKLeaked industry data, seen by the Mirror, shows there were , services in the week ending March  - down by , compared to a week in February . Yet more cuts are coming down the trackWaterloo station is busy with commuters at rush hour after lockdown restrictions are eased Image: Amer Ghazzal REX ShutterstockByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Apr |comments Almost , fewer trains are running per day than before Covid despite Boris Johnson ’s vow to ‘live with’ the virus.Leaked industry data seen by the Mirror shows there were , rail services in the week ending March . That is down by , since the , in the week ending  February . Rail services are battling Covid absences and a funding crisis - as there are still only % as many passengers travelling as pre-pandemic, the data shows. Passenger numbers have risen as fast as a million a week, hitting .million weekly journeys in the most recent figures. But this is down from .million weekly journeys pre-pandemic. And despite fares rising .% last month, services are still being cut to save cash. More cuts are planned in Yorkshire next month - leaving a two-hour, ten-minute gap between the .pm and .pm service from Leeds to Harrogate.  Labour, which obtained the leaked Rail Delivery Group data, blasted the figures just months after Tory ministers vowed to “protect and improve services” in the Integrated Rail Plan.Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh said: “The Conservatives should come clean and admit they are taking the axe to vital rail services across the country. “This is the exact opposite of what the Conservatives promised, and will hit communities hard. “To add insult to injury, last month they clobbered passengers with another brutal fare hike.” The Rail Delivery Group said it was “only sensible” that services reflect the “new world” of passenger numbers that have “changed radically with the pandemic”, “so that the railway doesn’t take more than its fair share from the taxpayer”. Askedservices would ever get back to what they were in early , a spokesperson said: “Nothing is set in stone and we will continually monitor how passengersand look to step up services where there is enough demand from passengers.”  It comes days after local leaders said they were “shafted” by Boris Johnson’s bus funding which went to fewer than half of eligible areas. A Department for Transport spokesperson said: “The railways experienced an unprecedented fall in passenger numbers during the pandemic. “Not adjusting rail services would have been irresponsible and unfair on those taxpayers’ forced to foot the bill – many of whom do not use the railways. “Instead, this Government committed almost £bn to ensure vital services continued to run and key workers were able to keep using them. “Whilst passengers are ing, it is important to ensure service levels reflect demand, which is still % less than in , and we will keep working with operators to do so.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyDepartment for TransportBoris JohnsonRailwaysSave moneyPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tory held seaside towns pushed
story: Exclusive: Tory-held seaside towns to be pushed into poverty by Rishi Sunaks cost of living failureDespite pleas from Conservative MPs not to hit wage packets with a .% national insurance hike, the Chancellor went ahead last week anywayHastings is among the towns at risk of poverty Image: Daily MirrorByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr  Tory-held seaside towns are likely to be pushed into poverty by Rishi Sunak ’s failure to tackle the cost of living crisis, says a new report.Despite pleas from Conservative MPs not to hit wage packets with a .% national insurance hike, the Chancellor went ahead last week anyway. Coastal areas were already suffering hits as even low paid seasonal work dried up with so many holidaymakers jetting off to foreign hotspots instead. Local economies struggled even more as young people moved away to find jobs where. Now think tank the Centre for Progressive Policy has plotted the areas likely to suffer most from this year’s soaring prices. They pinpointed seaside resorts Thanet, Great Yarmouth, Hastings, Tendring, Essex, Torbay and the Isle of Wight - all held by Tory MPs - at particular risk.  Seaports Portsmouth, where one in three jobs are low paid, and Dover - hit by PO’s sudden sacking of  seafarers - are also on the poverty list.The CPP’s Ben Franklin said: “Our analysis suggests the Chancellor may be forced to reconsider a Universal Credit uplt to really help those hit hardest in places like Hartlepool and Hastings.”And shadow Levelling Up Secretary Lisa Nandy added: “This new research reveals the inadequacy of the Government’s response to the cost-of-living crisis facing families. “We need to get money back into people’s pockets.”The CPP used indicators such as existing fuel and food poverty, benefit claimant count, joblessness and low pay to come up with a cost of living vulnerability index. That showed that Thanet has more than one in five residents struggling with food bills, one in ten with fuel, a child poverty rate of % and % not working. A quarter of those in work in Great Yarmouth are on low pay while one in three children live in poverty. But South Thanet Tory MP Craig Mackinlay, which has Kent seaside resorts Broadstairs and Ramsgate in his constituency, was upbeat on the prospects for his patch.  He said: “Going to Spain is going to be a lot more expensive this year. “So tourism here could actually increase what with fuel costs, flight disruption and people getting more used to staycations during the pandemic.” And at least one seaside town has avoided going into decline as the holiday trade disappeared by ersying into other areas. Briighton on the south coast is booming thanks to drawing on the skilled labour from its two universities for digital and creative industries. title: torys levelling up department offering
story: Torys Levelling Up department offering salaries of £, for regional directorsThe successful Levelling Up candidates – who will receive almost five times the salary of the average council worker – are expected to “live, breathe and champion” the places they represent Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByJack Clover:,  Apr |comments Michael Gove’s Levelling Up department has been criticised for offering to pay its regional directors £,.Job adverts published this week say the  roles will provide a “once-in-a-letime opportunity”. But critics fear the posts will be offered to ex-town hall officials in a revolving door of failure. The successful candidates – who will receive almost five times the salary of the average council worker – are expected to “live, breathe and champion” the places they represent. But it remains unclear what the roles will actually involve. The Levelling Up department was created to “drive prosperity” across the whole of the UK, not just London.  Wolverhampton, Truro in Cornwall and Hastings in East Sussex are among the areas looking for directors. But John O’Connell, chief executive of the TaxPayers’ Alliance, said: “These pricey pen-pushers will end up costing the very people they’re trying to help a fortune in taxes. The best way to level up is by allowing families and firms to keep more of their own money and giving them more say over how taxes are spent.” The job news comes after it emerged some , council fatcats pocketed more than £, last year. Lisa Nandy, Shadow Levelling Up Secretary, said: “It is vital these directors provide value for money for the taxpayer and understand the communities they are serving. “Levelling Up can’t be about rearranging the deckchairs or more bureaucracy – it’s about good jobs for everyone, money in people’s pockets, and empowering people to make the decisions that affect communities.”Harry Quilter-Pinner, director of the IPPR think-tank, warned against recruiting from the “old guard” oflocal politics and said the Government must instead “reach out to women, people of colour and people from working-class backgrounds”.A government spokesman said: “Directors will be working collaboratively with local leaders across all sectors to drive innovative proposals.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Sunday MirrorLevelling Up Watch,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: selfless mum dubbed angel helping
story: Selfless mum dubbed angel for helping others in cost-of-living nightmareKaren Noble and The Pallion Action Group make a real dference at the heart of their community, thanks to funding that you help raise by playing The Health LotteryKaren Noble is the manager of The Pallion Action GroupAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Apr “Bingo and Broth” or “Quiche and Quiz” are just two events that tempt people into Sunderland’s The Pallion Action Group – but the community centre and its friendly staff offer so much more. Manager Karen Noble is on a mission to make sure people are getting the support and benefits they need – and this is particularly important for older visitors, who might feel isolated. “It’s not just about organising activities they can get involved with: conversations might come out of that,” says Karen. “People will tell you what they’re struggling with and how you can support them. You might find out that they’ve been given an iPad but have no internet connection, or that they don’t feel safe because some kids have been throwing eggs in the streets. “We have a lot of older people who shouldbe receiving benefits but they’re not. So we want to get that message out to them. They’ll go ‘No, I’m alright’ because there is a bit of pride there – but we want to make sure they get everything they’re entitled to.”Karen is devoted to helping people in the local community because she knows what it’s like to struggle. As a young mum of two, she worked and had to battle to support her children. “I had to fight to make sure I got all the right benefits – and then people saw what I did and started coming to me for help,” says Karen. Welcome new players! BeGambleAware.org She then started to volunteer – and found her vocation, which led her to Pallion, where her nickname is Community Angel. Over the past month Karen has noticed more people than ever need help as fuel bills rise and the cost-of-living crisis bites. “The fuel hikes aren’t in line with people’s wages and benefits, so we’re helping as much as we can. But we don’t just want to stick a plaster over it. Do we need to get people into better-paid jobs  Do we need to upskill them ” she asks. “There are lots of reasons why people are struggling now. They might have lost their jobs or used up their savings during the Covid pandemic. Some people are on benefits – but we’ve got a lot of people who are working hard just to put food on the table.” The Pallion Action Group is just one of the projects that has received funding from Peopleaposs Health Trust with money raised through The Health Lottery, and every time you play you’re supporting local communities like these. More than £million has been given to over , projects, making a real dference to more than , people’s lives. Many good causes have been supported, including help for people with dementia, loneliness, learning dficulties and mental health issues thanks to the Health Lottery.“Without funding raised through The Health Lottery we’d be operating on a shoestring – and asking our staff to do things for nothing when they’re struggling as well,” says Karen. “I thinkyou’re buying a Health Lottery ticket, you’re winning anyway. Evenyou don’t win any money, you’re helping to fund projects in your local community. news uk-news asda-tesco-iceland-issue-urgent-"Food recalls arent that common says expert in ByLottie Gibbons:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Several supermarkets have issued urgent warnings as products are pulled from shelves. Customers are being urged to check their kitchens in case they have any unsafe products on the go, reports the Liverpool Echo.It comes after Kinder products became under threat of contamination from Salmonella, forcing a factory in Belgium to close after over  people came down with the bug. Other products have been found to contain high levels of E. coli. Asda, Tesco, Morrisons are among the supermarket giants to have recalled items in recent weeks, with consumers told tothem to the store for a full refund.You do not need to have your receipt to get your money back. When a product is recalled, for any reason, the Food Safety Agencyshares details on what you should doyou have bought the item, as well as detailed information on why the product is being pulled from shelves.  Ferrero is extending their precautionary action of recalling additional Kinder products because they might be contaminated with Salmonella. This is an update to include additional Kinder products and best before dates. Product details Kinder SurprisePack size:  g and  g x  Best-before dates: all dates up to and including  October Kinder SurprisePack size:  g Best-before dates: all dates from  April  up to and including  August Kinder Mini EggsPack size:  g Best-before dates: all dates from  April  up to and including  August Kinder Egg Hunt KitPack size:  g Best-before dates: all dates from  April  up to and including  August Kinder SchokobonsPack size:  g Best-before dates: all dates from  April  up to and including  August Symptoms caused by Salmonella usually include fever, diarrhoea and abdominal cramps.If you have bought the above products do not eat them. Instead, please contact the Ferrero consumer careline on consumers.uk@ferrero or    UK or +    Ireland to obtain a full refund.Tesco  As a precaution, Trewithen Dairy is recalling one batch code of its unsalted butter, as it’s been found to contain high levels of E. coli.Trewithen Dairy Unsalted Butter G Best before date:  May  Batch code: G No other Trewithen Dairy products are known to be affected. If you’ve bought an affected product, please don’t eat it. Instead,it to a Tesco store where a full refund will be given. No receipt is required. For more information, you can contact Trewithen Dairy Customer Services on   . Iceland Iceland is recalling Iceland Takeaway Chicken Bhunabecause it contains milk which is not declared on the label. As a result of a packaging error, some packs may contain Iceland Takeaway Creamy Butter Chicken. This means the product is a possible health risk for anyone with an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents. Product details Iceland Takeaway Chicken BhunaPack size:  g Batch code: L Best-before date:  January  Allergen: milkIf you have bought the above product and have an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents do not eat it. Insteadit to the store from where it was bought for a full refund. If you have any questions or concerns, you can contact Iceland customer care telephone line on   . title: asda uks cheapest supermarket easter
story: Asda is the UKs cheapest supermarket for Easter egg bargain huntersAsda was cheaper or the same price for four Easter eggs, while Lidl and Morrisons were cheaper or the same price for three eggs each, says Which Its Easter egg season Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByStephen Hayward:,  Apr |commentsEaster egg bargain hunters will shell out less at Asda, a choc poll reveals. Researchers compared branded eggs at eight leading supermarkets and checked each one for the best price.Asda was cheaper or the same price for four Easter eggs, while Lidl and Morrisons were cheaper or the same price for three eggs each, says Which Britain’s priciest Easter treat is a £ Ferrero Rocher Egg at Sainsbury’s. The same egg is £ less at Asda and Tesco, and a pound less from the Ocado home delivery service. In contrast, a giant Cadbury Crunchie Egg from Asda is one of this year’s best value treats, says consumer champion Which At £., it’s nearly twice as big as the g Ferrero Rocher version and more than £. cheaper. The same g Cadbury Crunchie treat cost £ at Tesco and Ocado. Researchers compared branded eggs at eight leading supermarkets and checked each one for the best price. Morrisons had the best value Dairy Milk Egg and Cadbury Mini Eggs at £ each. They were £ cheaper than Tesco, Britain’s biggest retailer. But Sainsbury’s had the cheapest mini egg - a g Cadbury Dairy Milk with Oreo costing just p. The same egg was p at Morrisons and Waitrose. Ocado and Waitrose weren’t the cheapest for any of the eggs in the Which  Easter basket.  A p Cadbury Creme Egg from Aldi, Asda and Lidl cost £. at Waitrose. Last year Britons shelled out £million on Easter eggs, down from £m in  and £m in , according to data firm Kantar. Not all the eggs checked by Which  were available at every supermarket. It says budget chains Aldi and Lidl stock fewer branded products than traditional supermarkets. Which  money editor Reena Sewraz said: “With a dference of over £. on a giant Easter egg, our analysis shows how important it is to shop around, especiallyyou have a specic brand in mind. “Anyone looking to stretch their cash even further should check the supermarket’s own brand options which might be just as tasty for a fraction of the price.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AsdaEaster eggsSupermarketsSunday Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the Secret Elves for celebration inspiration - and brilliant gt ideas and reviewsSpread the cheer!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: brave woman shares trauma being
story: Brave woman shares trauma of being forced to have sex with  men a day by gangNataliehas bravely spoken about the "most traumatic time" when she was trafficked into the UK, taken by a gang and locked in a room, tasered, and forced to have threesomes was kidnapped from a Welsh city and trafficked to three cities in England as a sex worker." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _GMP_WOL_Sex_worker_JPG.jpg" width"" "" Natalie: It was terrying, especially the traumaImage: WalesOnline  Gayle MarshByMatt StrudwickLiz Perkins:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr  has bravely spoken about the most traumatic time when she was trafficked into the UK, taken by a gang and locked in a room, tasered, and forced to have threesomes" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _GMP_WOL_Sex_worker_JPG.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" has bravely spoken about the most traumatic time when she was trafficked into the UK, taken by a gang and locked in a room, tasered, and forced to have threesomes" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _GMP_WOL_Sex_worker_JPG.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" has bravely spoken about the most traumatic time when she was trafficked into the UK, taken by a gang and locked in a room, tasered, and forced to have threesomes" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _GMP_WOL_Sex_worker_JPG.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"Natalie was just aged  when she was kidnapped by a gang, tied up, and locked away in a room. Trafficked into the UK, she was tasered and forced to have threesomes, gang bangs, and sleep with  men a night. “It was the most traumatic time of my le, she says. Her horric ordeal left her with addictions to drugs and sex after she was farmed around dferent cities as her home was turned into a drugs hub.Natalie, who is going under a dferent name, said she would be lucky to get two hours’ sleep a night and wouldn’t see a penny from her sex work that she carried out over  months in dferent cities across the UK, reports WalesOnline. I had tasers to me, she says, At the time I did not realise how bad it actually was. It was a gang who kidnapped me and held me captive. I was stuck in my bedroom with a lock on the door and they took over my house. I was not there for  months and it was like a drugs hub, I was not sure what was going on.”  A victim of child abuse had made her vulnerable and she says she was naive as to how the gang had operated, who had been operating in Wales for two decades, Natalie says. She adds: “I was taken to Liverpool, that was probably the scariest time. That was the first time I was tied up. If I had spoken out I would have been killed and I thought my daughter would have it, it was mad.” At the time, Natalie admits she was a cocaine addict which left her in their debt and under their control. She continues: “They had seen the amount of money I was spending on cocaine - I was a coke addict. I was buying coke off them. It’s how I became involved in all of it.. I was sold to the sex trade.... I needed someone to find me.” As she was trafficked across Britain she barely slept to keep up with the demands of her kidnappers. The horror of being raped and abused is one she was familiar with. “Sometimes I would have sex  or  times a day all day,” she says. “I would only have two hours’ sleep a day and not even that. Me and my associate would be made to do stuff together and made more money. I would have to have threesomes and gang bangs. It was terrying, especially the trauma.”  She adds: “I was there for  months, that was not just in that one city it was everywhere. It was not in one place. I was in Liverpool for six weeks, I was not allowed out, I was in a room. I think I went to the south of the country after that - it was not as bad. “Obviously, it’s bad but I didn’t have tasers to me - it wasn’t as damaging there. I was there .for about four months, it was a normal house. London and Liverpool was the scariest one. London was bad - it was worst than the city in the south. I was in London for about six months, all I would do is work. In the whole time I didn’t sleep in any way and I couldn’t really sleep. After I had been gone for four months I never thought anyone would find me. Natalie has since been able to turn her le around, but the emotional scars remain and she still lives in fear. It was only on herto Wales that the brutal reality of her existence was finally uncovered but it was a struggle to speak out and reveal what had happened to her. The challenge now is living with the fear the crime gang remain at large. Natalie, now , said she was worried she would be discovered. “They didn’t jail them they are still out there,” she says. “They have been arrested but no jail sentence has been given for it. I get scared they may find me, I am petried. Now I just feelthey wanted to find me they probably would. I think I have moved on even to do with sex work, all that has all stopped. It’s because I had a sex addiction and I have seen love as through sex. aposFor me to be proud of myself is a thingapos Her le since her abduction has not been easy. She has endured spells of homelessness and drug abuse and found it dficult to maintain relationships. She ed to sex work on the streets when she did not know what  to do, although she says she has not done sex work for two years now. She has had four children, none of whom are in her care. Yet she says she has beaten her addictions to cocaine and crack cocaine and now only smokes weed. Her addiction to sex has been tougher to break and is something she still wrestles with.Natalie says: “My sex addiction was hard to overcome, I was working with BAWSO [an organisation that provides emotional support to black minority ethnic and migrant victims of domestic abuse, sexual violence, human trafficking]- I had  sessions and four extra sessions so I had a total of  hours support to help me,” she says. “I had to retrain my brain.I was working with a support group and I ended up working with one of the workers. She helped me a lot with my sex addiction -I do not have sex for two weeks I am fine. It’s breaking the cycle of not wanting it all of the time. She says she is now focused on her children and has been through three years of intensive support thanks to Safer Wales, which offers support to those who are invisible in society and work to protect victims of sexual exploitation from danger. Without them the woman would not have been able to move on into a dferent le and have a roof over her head. Her plan is to build a brighter future for not just herself but others who have struggled through their teens. “My Safer Wales worker has been there for tears and laughter, she has been through my three-year journey,” she said. “For me to be proud of myself is a thing - I was never proud before, now I could not be happier. “Two weeks ago I was given my flat - it’s all guns going with all the decorating. I think of the now, I try to bury everything - I shouldn’t but I do. I want to go to uni and do health and social care and open a rehab from  to -year-olds, I want to help people who have gone through dficult times when they are going through adolescence and offer a better start in the care system.” Natalie adds: “If I had a better start in le I would not have got into a situation of drugs and the trafficking. I never thought I was going to survive - it was like my world had ended and I was a no one.” Read MoreRead More Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON ProstitutionCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news british-gas-customers-claim-something-"Smart meter change that could reduce household energy billsByMatthew EvansRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Apr |comments British Gas customers claim something fishy is going on with their smart meters amid the cost of living crisis.Complaints have been flooding the energy and home service provideraposs online forums with unsubstantiated claims of overcharging, and the app not working correctly since February.It comes as energy prices began to soar this year as a result of the Covid pandemic, as well as Ukraine invasion and ongoing Brexit aftermath. And Brits have been united in their despair, reports NorthWalesLive. National Insurance, council tax, and food and fuel prices have all increased due to the crisis, and experts have warned that the spikes wonapost start slowing anytime soon. Those that use smart meters were all under the impression that this would help keep cost down and also under control, as it helps monitor the bills. Unfortunately, customers of British Gas have come out in their droves complaining about something fishy going on.Love was certainly not lost on aposThe British Gas complaints pageapos Facebook page. Have you been experiencing similar problems  Let us know at webnews@mirror Sharon Backhouse said: How the hell can BG charge me £ in  minutes when I have no heating on  Amy Evans warned: Keep a close eye on your accounts. After querying what the cost says on my smart meter I was then told this was correct. £ electricity in  days! Again queried this suddenly it went down and after further query went down again. Something fishy going on! Julie Rose brought up the issues of home discounts. She said: Still not got home discount. Iaposve got a  year old in house with a coat on and hot water bottle and blanket. Our Cost of Living team of experts are here to help YOU through a very dficult year. Theyaposll be bringing you the latest money news stories and also providing specialist advice. Whether itaposs rocketing energy bills, the cost of the weekly shop or increased taxes, our team will be with you all the way. Every Thursday at pm they will take part in a Facebook Live event to answer your questions and offer their advice. Visit facebook dailymirror live to watch. You canabout our team of experts here. If you have a question - or want to share your story - please get in touch by emailing webnews@mirror. Iaposve explained this to BG and said they canapost tell me when it will be sent out to me and they can see Iaposm entitled to it but canapost even put it on my meter at there end. Are they having a laugh  Fuming not the word. In response, Charlene Borsberry said: Told me I didnapost even apply for it but why am I surprised [after] they stole last yearaposs from me  Iaposve had  years of dealing with them constantly cutting us off or letting us down. I have  children, one who needs medical equipment. They know all this. They just donapost care...as long as the big wigs are sitting pretty. Iaposm done, Iaposve started the switch. Canapost handle the stress. Disgusting company!  Anne OaposShiel apparently managed to get through to British Gas, who gave a date for customers expecting payments. She posted: Finally spoke to BG re my Warm Home Discount. I was informed that everyone should receive their payments by th April. If nothing has been received by then, to call back  only then, can they make payment, directly to the meter...! Nicky Hitchcock was equally outraged about the apparent overcharging. She said: We were on a fixed tarf of £ per month, which ended in December.  They then put us up to £ per month and have now recommend we pay  PER MONTH, even though we’ve never been in debit! Three bedroom semi-detached, not a mansion! We now only use the boiler for  hour each morning to provide some hot water for the day and then wrap up in thermals for the rest of our time in the house! What do British Gas say  NorthWalesLive has reached out to British Gas for a response to these claims. From their help page they found the following: If your meter isnapost workingIf your pay as you go meter is damaged, we can send someone out to make sure you and your property are safe. Just call us on our as you go enquiries line.This line is open Monday to Friday am to pm for general enquiries and  hours a day, seven days a week for emergencies. If you donapost have a pay as you go meter please call us on our Account enquiries line. Whatmy meteraposs damaged If thereaposs something wrong with your gas meter, thataposs worrying. Immediately get in touch with the Gas Emergency Services. If you notice any sparking, smoking or burning coming from your meter, ring the fire brigade. Turn off all your appliances and call your local electricity distributor.Whatmy meter reading hasnapost changed, or is going backwards Your meter may be recording your energy use incorrectly. If you have a pay as you go meter call us on our Pay as you go enquiries line as soon as possible to make sure youaposre only paying for what youaposve used. If you donapost have a pay as you go meter call us on our Account enquiries line Why has my smart meter stopped working We need to establishthe problem is with your smart meters or your smart energy monitor. Follow this link here to checkthe problem could be with your smart energy monitor. If this hasn’t resolved the issue, occasionally there are problems with the technology that supports smart meters. We investigate any issues on a case by case basis work out what we can do to help you. title: hero holds dying dads hand
story: Hero holds dying dads hand and tells him his daughter is safe after horror crashHGV technician Steve Wroe, , joined a group of heroic rescuers who saved a teenage girls le after a lorry and car collided on the M near Goole, in the East Riding of YorkshireTwo men were killed after a HGV and car crashed on the M near Goole Image: MEN MEDIAByEmily JohnsonRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Apr |comments A heroic passing motorist who fought desperately to save the victims of a horror crash said he held the hand of a dying driver and told him his daughter was safe.Steve Wroe embarked on the daring rescue alongside other witnesses after spotting the carnage on the M which saw two men die.The -year-old said he wanted one of the fatalitiesapos families to know he was aware his daughter was safe when he passed away, reports Hull Live.A HGV and a car had collided on the motorway near Goole, in the East Riding of Yorkshire, at around .am last Wednesday.According to the latest reports from Humberside Police, a -year-old girl remains in hospital. Steve, from Huddersfield, said he and a group of men battled to save the girl, who had been travelling in the HGV, which had set on fire. Have you been affected by this story  Let us know at webnews@mirror The Good Samaritan described how, despite his best efforts, he was unable to free the lorryaposs -year-old driver. Instead, Steve held his hand and was not willing to leave his side as he succumbed to his injuries. Fighting back tears, he said: I tried my hardest and I feel like Iaposve failed the family because I couldnapost do more. I just really need his family to know that the last words he heard were that we saved his daughter and she was safe. I had hold of his hand and kept telling him I was sorry, right until his final moments.  After seeing the accident ahead, Steve said he ran down the slip road and set out to rescue those involved. He was joined by three other men who were attempting to force open the damaged door of the HGV involved and smashed the passenger window. Steve has decades of experience as a HGV technician, and directed the men to focus on freeing the teenager from the vehicle, while he turned his attention on the man in the driveraposs seat. They attempted to use a fire extinguisher to put out the flames but it was not holding them back. Steve held the manaposs hand as it became clear he was unable to be rescued.It reached a point where I told him that I had to go and he passed in a matter of seconds afterwards. He wasnapost suffering for a long time and we made sure to stay with him as long as possible. The only other option would have been to get in the cabin with him, but there was just so much fire and smoke. He continued: It wasnapost safe to do anything more and I had to think about my own family in that moment as well. Steve described the other rescuers as  out of  and true heroes. I can only hope the girl is doing okay, he added. A -year-old man, who was driving the car involved in the accident, also died in the crash on April . Steveaposs boss Oliver North picked him up from the hospital in the aftermath and said his work kit was completely charred and his face was still covered in soot. He said: Steve was coughing and choking, heaposd been on oxygen for two hours after the incident. We think he is an absolute hero and a truly unbelievable man. The thing is, Steve would never have usually been down that way as he is mainly based in Brighouse.He added that his firm is building ambulances for Ukraine, and Steve was driving parts down to its Goole factory.He is so passionate about saving lives that he wanted to get involved in the project in any way he could, thataposs just who he is, continued Oliver. It is no surprise that he didnapost hesitate to run down that slip road and do all he could to help those victims. Steve is set toto work on Monday at his own request but has been given a present by his colleagues. news uk-news i-spent--asda-smart-"Cost of Living: Reporter impressed by Asda Smart Price dealsByEmma Gill:,  Apr |comments The weekly supermarket shop can be a stressful endeavour, especially during these times of economic hardship for many families. The cost of living crisis is hitting Brits hard and tough decisions are having to be made every day.Energy bills and council tax is going up, as is the cost of fuel, and it means seeking out a bargain where you can.As such, shoppers are trying to cut back wherever possible, reports the Manchester Evening News.For many that means changing shopping habits and paying a lot more attention to whataposs being spent at the supermarket.Have you found any cost-saving hacks  Let us know at webnews@mirror While some people may turn their noses up at budget ranges, thereaposs a reason why the likes of Asda Smart Price and Morrisons Savers have become so popular. Itaposs because they offer decent products at great value for money. Same goes for the likes of budget retailers Aldi and Lidl. Our Cost of Living team of experts are here to help YOU through a very dficult year. Theyaposll be bringing you the latest money news stories and also providing specialist advice. Whether itaposs rocketing energy bills, the cost of the weekly shop or increased taxes, our team will be with you all the way. Every Thursday at pm they will take part in a Facebook Live event to answer your questions and offer their advice. Visit facebook dailymirror live to watch. You canabout our team of experts here. If you have a question - or want to share your story - please get in touch by emailing webnews@mirror. Admittedly some of it is not to everyoneaposs taste - you canapost get the lowest fat versions of meat and cheese, for example. But when needs must, the priority is putting food on the table and doing it the cheapest and healthiest way you can. And itaposs easy to overlook the essentials you buy week-in week-out. If you bought these basic Smart Price versions, they would make little dference to the overall taste of your meals but a massive dference to your bank balance. Thataposs not to mention the whopping bags of potatoes, .kg for p, and carrots, .kg for p, from its budget fruit, veg and meat range.  Those prices are pretty much on a par with Aldiaposs Everyday Essentials wonky veg and we all know how much people rave about those. You can save on meat too, with chicken breasts costing around £. for a large g pack and bacon £. for g. There was no p Smart Price bread in stock, but Asdaaposs own comes in at a very reasonable p for an g loaf and is one thing that is worth spending those extra pennies on. But there are plenty more products where savings can be made,youaposre willing to sacrice your fancy labels. Do you really care that much about your brand of loo roll or cleaner to splash out on something thataposs quite literally going down the toilet   My haul of products from Asdaaposs budget ranges cost me just over £ and Iaposll be honest, it made me feel a bit of a fool. A fool for poo-pooing these budget brands for so many years without considering which items I could so easily swap into my weekly shop without sacricing quality or taste. From now on, itaposll be the p toilet cleaner going down the pan and not my hard earned cash. Itaposs all about playing it Smart. title: martin lewis fans share tips
story: Martin Lewis fans share tips on cooking a family meal for p with just one potConcerned by the rising cost of living, Martin Lewis and his Money Saving Expertteam asked their social media followers for their best tips to help Brits who are struggling team asked their followers for tips to help people who are struggling financially amid the cost of living crisis" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Irish-stew-in-a-slow-cooker-pot.jpg" width"" "" Martin Lewis and his Money Saving Expertteam asked their followers for tips to help people who are struggling financially amid the cost of living crisis Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJenna ThompsonRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr  team asked their social media followers for their best tips to help Brits who are struggling" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Irish-stew-in-a-slow-cooker-pot.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" team asked their social media followers for their best tips to help Brits who are struggling" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Irish-stew-in-a-slow-cooker-pot.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" team asked their social media followers for their best tips to help Brits who are struggling" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Irish-stew-in-a-slow-cooker-pot.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"|commentsMartin Lewis fans have been sharing tips on how struggling families can slash the cost of family meals. Martin Lewis and his Money Saving Expertteam asked social media followers for their best tips to help people who are suffering amid the c ost-of-living crisis. The team has compiled the Cost of Living Survival Guide to help Brits weather the price hikes, Hull Live reports.Families are expected to feel the sting this month as energy bills and National Insurance are increased. Council tax, fuel prices and food are also going up, leading to more people feeling the pinch. Introducing his teamaposs tips, Martin Lewis wrote: For some there is sadly no route to cut expenditure below income that fix will need political intervention.  For others, we need a collective endeavour, to work together to take financial pressures off where we can. And that is partly behind this guide. He explained the team had received thousands of replies from people with clever ideas about how to cut household expenditure. Martin described the response - which included more than , replies to his tweet alone - as overwhelming and uplting. One of the tips was to invest in a slow cooker to batch cook meals for all the family. They are available from Asda for as little as £. The Money Saving Expert team said batch cooking creates less food waste and reduces the likelihood of spending extra cash on takeaways.  One follower said they are apossaving a fortuneapos by using theirs more and more. Sharron Quaile wrote: A chef was on TV recently telling us all to get a slow cooker, as it costs p to cook a meal overnight. Made a cracking chilli the other night, gave my neighbour a portionand thereaposs one portion in the freezer. A user under the name of Living in Hope wrote: Iaposm using my slow cooker more and more these days to batch cook delicious soups, curries, stews etc then I freeze it in recycled takeaway containers. Saves a fortune all round. They added it did not cost much to invest in. It’s a standard sized one, only cost me about £ - very simple, no whistles or bells, but does the job, they wrote. The MSE guide also says that using a microwave is generally cheaper than an oven. It states a jacket potato would be more than  per cent cheaper to cook in the microwave rather than the oven. title: my dog saved life became
story: My dog saved my le when I became homeless but I cant get a home because of himMick, , who lives on the streets of London with his -year-old Staffordshire Bull Terrier Benson, was made homeless after losing his job and then his home in Mick and his pet pooch Benson Image: StreetVetByTara CobhamRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A homeless man canapost secure a place to live because hostels wonapost take him in with the dog that saved his le. Mick lost his job and then his home before ending up on the streets of London with his Staffordshire Bull Terrier, Benson, in . He told MyLondon : “Without him, I think I would have gone under.And he wouldn’t be able to survive without me, simply because of our bond. We’re together  . He understands me, I understand him. He’s the only thing I put my trust into and he’s never let me down.” But because of his beloved -year-old pooch, the Londoner has struggled for seven years to get housing. Their bond has only grown stronger over the years since Mick, who asked to only be called his first name, adopted Benson from his previous owner, who couldnapost take care of him anymore, at -months-old.  “How could I say no to him ” said the Londoner lovingly. “When he was three, I lost my job, then couldn’t afford my rent so lost my property, and ended up on the streets. I wrestled with my conscience over whether it was right to keep him - but he’s been through so much upheaval, I couldn’t not.”The duo appeared on the hit ITV show Paul OaposGrady: For the Love of Dogs and are known in their local area, around Liverpool Street and Hackney, with people like the shop owners, taxi drivers and station owners all keeping an eye on Benson.“I’m always conscious of him - that people might try and take him, said the -year-old, Rest and sleep is the hardest thing on the streets - you’re sleeping with one eye open.” He said: “Everything has to be centred around him and I have to worry about what’s going to happen to him. And then you can’t take him to certain services.”This includes many accommodation options for those who are experiencing homelessness. In fact, only around  percent of hostels in the UK are pet friendly, according toStreetVet , a charity working to increase this statistic and delivering free veterinary care to the pets of people experiencing homelessness around the country. According to StreetVet, to apply for housing benefits, some form of address is required. A hostel address is usually used for this, but as Mick said he struggles to get into hostels with Benson, he is unable to even get started with the benefits process. He also noted that many housing associations will not accept dogs. “You get accused of making yourself intentionally homeless so they don’t take any responsibility,” he said. “I’ve been trying to get housed for seven years. You get the choice between your room and your pet - that’s not a choice. They’re not acknowledging the support of Benson as important in my le, despite my health conditions.” Mick suffers with anxiety and depression, which he said contributed to losing his job. He believes he would have turned to drink and drugsit had not been for Benson. He said: “He’s my escape and gives me something to focus on. He’s a mainstay in my le and keeps me grounded. If he’s not around me, I feel lost - I feel secure when I’m with him. He’s not so much for protection as he is for comfort. You look at him and think, ‘It ain’t all bad - Iaposve got him. As long as I’ve got him, I’m okayapos. He added: “When you’re on the street, so many things can happen. If I start getting heated with someone, he can bring me back down. He reminds me that there are more important things. If anything would happen to me, then what would happen to him  If anything happened to him, then that would kill me, andanything happened to me then that would kill him - that’s it.” Mick claims that Bensonaposs role in apossaving his leapos has not been taken into consideration in his attempts to find a home for the both of them. Even during the pandemic, he claims he was not offered a room with his dog. He added: “I’d sooner take the risk on the street with my boy than be separated from him - simple. He also says knows some people have only just had their pets ed to them.He said: “The authorities didn’t grasp the bond between man and dog.” Founder of StreetVet Jade Statt explained that some places in the UK were better than others at housing owners with their pets - but the resounding feedback from her clients was that a poor effort was made in London. “They didn’t realise that people who have pets and are homeless are much less likely to engage in antisocial behaviour because that would end up in them being separated from their dog. You have a reason, a role, a responsibility,” said Jade. She added: “Because that dog was everything to them”. Summing up his dreams for the future, Mick said: “My dream is to have somewhere to call home - a self-contained property where me and Benson can live out our days. title: primary school kids taught how
story: Exclusive: Primary school kids taught how to spot cannabis gummies that look like sweetsSweets have been banned from some schools after drug dealers hid intoxicants in treats that look like Haribo. Last month, law student Damilola Olakanmi, , died after eating a suspected cannabis gummyKids are being taught how to spot drug sweets Image: Getty ImagesByAmy SharpeNews Reporter:,  Apr Schools are teaching primary kids about deadly cannabis “gummies” which look like harmless sweets. Some have banned candy altogether over reports of pushers selling drugs disguised as brands like Haribo. They contain synthetic cannabis, sometimes known as spice, which can cause hallucinations, paranoia and even death. Last month, law student Damilola Olakanmi, , died after eating a suspected cannabis gummy. She had ordered them on a phone app to be delivered to her home in Ilford, East London, the same day. Police have visited one school, Boundary Primary in Blackpool, to show pupils aged  and  the dference between real sweets and dodgy ones. Another school has banned youngsters from bringing any confectionary on site after Northumbria Police reports that gummies are being sold for as little as £. on Snapchat.Parents of children at Farringdon Community Academy in Sunderland have been warned that the drugs “look like normal packets of sweets but may have odd spellings and dferent fonts”. All Saints School in York also warned that sweets packaged to resemble brands like Haribo, Nerds and Millions are “of particular concern.” Officers seized £, of edible cannabis disguised as Dairy Milk and Milky Bars in Wakefield, West Yorks, in March. Police say county lines gangs use sweets to lure kids into dealing. Last week forces in the east of England said there were almost  reports of them being found over six months in . title: prince george taking after prince
story: Prince George taking after Prince William and Kate with particular sporting skillIt looks like Prince George is taking after his parents, Prince William and Kate Middleton, in more ways than one - including learning a particular sporting skillPrince George is set to take after his parents Image: PAByEmma RosemurgeyAudience WriterRebecca Russell:,  Apr |commentsPrince William and Kate recently ed from a royal tour of the Caribbean in celebration of the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee, where they engaged in a number of activities from bobsleighing in Jamaica to scuba ing in Belize.The couple are always keen to have a go at new activities but scuba ing is nothing new to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, with Wills taking on the presidency of the British Sub-Aqua Clubin .The Duke followed in the footsteps of his father, Prince Charles, and his grandfather, the late Prince Philip, who both previously held the title - and it looks like Prince George is set to follow suit. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Speaking to BSAC members at the time, William said it was a great honour to take on the role from his father and that he hoped one day George - who was just a baby at the time - would also follow in his footsteps. I hope that one day my son George might follow in our footsteps, he said. For the moment bath time is quite painful, but I imagine as he gets a little bit older, donning a mask and snorkel might calm him down. And, it seems as though George is doing exactly that, with rumours suggesting he is preparing to head to Lambrook school in September, where heaposll benefit from a whole host of extracurricular activities, including scuba ing. The school is reported to cost an eyewatering £, and £, per term, however it boasts everything from a nine-hole golf course, a polo field, beehives, fencing and a mini Masterchef club.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news uk-news prince-philips-poignant-last-words-"Prince Charles recalls his last phone call with Prince PhilipByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Apr |commentsWhen Prince Philip died last year, those closest to him spoke fondly of his humour and quick wit. As he saw out his final, peaceful days at Windsor Castle before he passed away aged , he seemingly retained his sense of fun. And, true to form, the -year-old couldnapost resist one last one wisecrack while speaking to his eldest son Prince Charles, the day before he died. In a documentary celebrating the le of his father, Charles recalled the last conversation he had over the phone with Philip just hours before his death.In an intimate interview for a BBC film, the Prince of Wales described how he tentatively broached the subject of Philipaposs upcoming th birthday and suggested a party, knowing it was something his dad was not keen on. And Charles revealed how Philipaposs response left him with one last happy memory of his dadaposs cheeky nature. He recalled he told the late Duke of Edinburgh that the family had been talking about his th birthday. Knowing his father was slightly hard of hearing, Charles then repeated himself more loudly, emphasising: aposWeaposre talking about your birthday! And whether thereaposs going to be a reception!apos  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up To which Charles said Philip replied sharply, without missing a beat: Well, Iaposve got to be alive for it, havenapost I  Charles then said: I told him aposI knew youaposd say that!apos and added that it was a happy memory.  Yesterday marked exactly one year since Philipaposs sad death, with the Royal Family marking the day in private. It is believed that his beloved we the Queen spent the anniversary at Windsor Castle. It came as the naval unorm worn by Philip along with his admiral’s cap went on display for the first time on the first anniversary of his death. The items are part of an exhibition at the National Museum of the Royal Navyin Portsmouth Historic Dockyard looking at the Queen’s close links to the Navy as part of celebrations for her Platinum Jubilee.As well as being the daughter and granddaughter of monarchs who served in the Navy, the Queen became an officer’s we when she married Philip.The exhibition also includes photographs depicting the Queen’s many engagements as ceremonial head of the Royal Navy. title: tornado strikes wales winds strong
story: Tornado strikes Wales with winds so strong ewe and her lambs carried into the airThe extreme weather struck Gogarth Hall Farm in Pennal - the Tornado and Storm Research Organisation said it believes that the damage was caused by a T tornadoDamage to Gogarth Hall Farm in Pennal Image: PAByTom DavidsonAssistant news editor:,  Apr |commentsStrong winds that caused at least £, of damage to a farm in North Wales have been confirmed as a tornado, according to experts.The extreme weather struck Gogarth Hall Farm in Pennal on Wednesday, uprooting trees and lting a ewe and lambs into the air.The Tornado and Storm Research Organisation said it had investigated the site and believed that the damage was caused by a T tornado. Investigator John Mason said objects had spun around before falling to the ground. The tornado was confirmed as there was plenty of evidence of objects being airborne and spinning around the circulation before falling to the ground, he said.  He added that he believed it had a strength of between mph-mph. Deilwen Breese, owner of Gogarth Hall Farm, said she was away from the farm when she received a phone call telling her to come home. Ms Breese told the PA news agency she did not realise the scale of the damage until she got back. I thought it was just that part of the roof had gone, she said. But oh my god, when I came home I could not believe it. Ms Breese said she was still in shock from the incident. The devastation, it was heartbreaking, she said. I am still in shock, really. Ms Breese added: Trees had been lted from their roots. If they hadnapost been lted they had just been tarnished. We have lost hundreds of trees. The winds were so strong that a ewe and its lambs were lted into the air. Ms Breese said: It took a ewe out through the bay of a shed, and it picked up the little lambs. She said the lambs were fine, but the ewe was gone. Ms Breese said that the damage to the roof was about £,. When I got to the farm I could see the damage to the roof, itaposs about £, worth of damage on the roof. She said a group of  local volunteers were now helping her clear the devastation. However, Ms Breese feels that the farm will not be the same. She said: Itaposs going to take months, it will never get back, not in my letime. It will never come back to what it was. news uk-news uks-biggest-family-radfords-dodge-"The Radfords share their plans to build their own homeByFatima Aziz:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsMembers of the UKaposs biggest family successfully navigated through chaos at Manchester Airport for an Easter getaway. Sixteen members of the Radford clan reached Florida despite previous worries of getting the brood through the long delays. Mum Sue and dad Noel successfully left their Morecambe home to jet off to a sunnier Florida where the kids can be seen having a blast as Disney World.Posting on Instagram Sue provided snippets of the journey including some brief shots in the airport, Lancashire Live reports.Clips show the kids running along the airport travellators, looking out at the window to the their plane and then finally, seated and on their way to the Easter holiday. But it wasnapost smooth sailing getting there. In a recent vlog, Sue spoke from the families home in Morecambe about the checklist of things needed to be done before getting on the plane. One of those tasks included getting a Covid test for everyone.  Speaking to fans in their aposmost tense vlog everapos, Sue explained that the day before they left for the airport they would have to take  Covid tests in appointment slots with an online witness. The four appointments included four family members at a time and just one negative test could write off the highly anticipated holiday for the entire family. Sue said: Iaposm hoping, fingers crossed, that everybody is negative. I canapost even begin to tell you how nervous I am about these tests. I did not sleep very well last night because obviouslysomeone is positive, we canapost go and weaposll have to rearrange it.I keep thinking it wonapost be the end of the worldwe do have to rearrange it, I think the situation with Manchester Airport at the minute is an absolute nightmare andIaposm honest, Iaposm not keen on doing that because I think itaposs taking two and a half, three hours, to get through security, checking-in as well is taking about an hour. Obviously when youaposve got sixteen of us, you can well double that, so probably about five hours for us by that time we probably would have missed our flight.  She continued: Iaposm not wanting to go through that, I must admit. So Iaposm thinking, it wonapost be the end of the worldone of us does test positive, we can just rearrange it for later in the year but obviously the kids will be absolutely devastated. But no signs of those fears affecting the trip were shown in the short but sweet video she posted. The only mention of the airport madness was in the comments as one person said: Oh Iaposm over the moon you are there and safe! The news is horrible re Manchester airport. Sue replied: It really is itaposs awful for all the staff on the frontline getting all the abuse. The Radfords continue to document their Easter break on Instagram with talk of a Disneyland vlog coming up too. title: man sends potential car buyer
story: Man sends potential car buyer on -mile wild goose chase after sick offerMechanic Janis Drikis, , says he was sickened when Charlie Murry, , offered him £ in cash for his Honda Civic that hed advertised at £, hoping for a quick saleJanis Drikis sent a potential car buyer on a wild goose chase after they made a very low offer Image: Kennedy News and MediaByJohn BettAudience WriterHannah Phillips:,  Apr |comments A man sent a potential car buyer on an -mile wild goose chase to a hospital and told him to aposget himself checkedapos after a apossickapos low offer.Mechanic Janis Drikis, , advertised his Honda Civic for just £ in the hope heaposd get a quick sale - but one potential buyer wanted it even cheaper. Charlie Murry, , offered him just £ in cash for the car - and instead of ignoring the offer or sending an angry reply, Janis decided to play along. He gave Charlie the address of a hospital, a two-hour drive away, and when he couldnapost find the fictional house, Janis told him to go in and aposmake an appointment and check yourselfapos for making such a low offer. What do you think about Janisapos revenge  Let us know in the comments...Janis, from Newry, Northern Ireland, said: I put the car for sale on Marketplace for £. I know there are people who are going to ask. I had lots of messages offering £ and £ and I donapost mindsomeone asks like that. I would probably ask. But I got that message for £ in cash and I thought aposJesus Christapos. It made me sick and I was just about to send some nice words but I sent him a thumbs up instead. He text back asking for my address so I gave him the address to a hospital. I thought I had to give him a good lesson. He askedIaposd be there all day and I put a thumbs up. The next day he text saying he couldnapost find my house so I directed him to the hospital. He text me saying he was at the hospital five minutes later. I told him to go make an appointment and check yourself for making that stupid offer. It was a good way to teach him a good lesson. He called me a rotten b*****d. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. He came from Ballymoney, which is hours away. I feel sorry about that but itaposs a good lesson for him. Charlie says heaposd been helping out at his sonaposs scrap business when heaposd offered to take the journey from Ballymoney to Newry to pick the car up. Charlie said: It was an MOT failure and had a blown turbo on it as well. It said that in the description. He had it up for £ and it was only for scrap. It could have been used againyou wanted to spend £, on it. If itaposs good enough to be used, why didnapost he take it back to MOT, repair it and drive it. My offer was fair, it was only good for scrap. All he had to do was send to my reply aposthataposs not enough. No thank youapos. I was pretty annoyed when I got there because it was an absolute low-down act to do on anybody. Iaposd understandit was a £, car and I offered dirty money for it but it was scrap. title: tattoo artist shares biggest mistakes
story: Tattoo artist shares biggest mistakes people make when getting their first inkA tattoo artist who is well known for sharing her experiences and warnings on TikTok has revealed some of the biggest mistakes people make when theyre getting their first ink Image: katiefromthepodcast  InstagramByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Apr |commentsTattoos last forever, so youaposll want to put a lot of thought into it before you commit - and there are a few things you should know. Tattoo artist Katie Baker has revealed the biggest mistakes people make when getting inked for the first time, so you donapost make them too. Katie has been been working as a tattooist for just over a year at Golden Skull Tattoo in Kennewick, Washington.She regularly posts videos on herTikTok @keeksandkooks , about her experiences there, whilst also educating her viewers about getting inked. Most recently, Katie shared tips and advice to tattoo newbies with Insider - and you might want to take notes. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Avoid going to artists who arenapost invested in your design Katie said one of the biggest mistakes someone can make is going to an artist who they donapost get along with. Getting a tattoo is a very intimate thing, and you want to make sure that you gel well with them when youaposre trusting them with your skin, she said. If you feel that your tattoo artist doesnapost respect you, run. She said she too often hears clients say that they had an artist who acted like they aposdidnapost careapos and this is a big red flag.Communicate with your artist Katie told the outlet that one of the things she was most surprised by was how much talking is incorporated into her job and that in order to understand her clientaposs vision she has to ensure mutual trust through communication. You really learn about peopleaposs hearts and who they are as people, Katie said before adding that it was one of the scariest parts of her job that sheaposs grown to love.Read MoreDo your research Katie said that some people are so eager to get a tattoo that they will visit any shop without taking the time to read reviews or thoroughly learn about their tattoo artist. She also said that some people would also overlookthe shop is clean orthe artists are drinking or taking drugs. In many of these cases, Katie said these clients end up getting the tattoo removed later down the line.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-splits-opinion-kicking-sand-"TikToker takes revenge on man who sat by her on empty beachByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Apr |comments A woman has ided opinion after she filmed herself kicking sand into the face of a man who sat down just -feet away from her, despite the beach being completely empty. Korynne @korynnecbegan feeling uncomfortable when she woke up from a nap on the beach, only to see a man sunbathing a close distance to her, leading her to worry he was stalking her. Convinced he was up to something sinister, the TikToker decided to get her own back at the man, by running past him and kicking sand in his face as she did so, the Daily Star reports. In a video she posted on TikTok, she said: When an old man parks himself -feet in front of your towel on a completely empty beach while you were napping and you know what needs to be done. Korynne filmed the beach to show the vast space with absolutely no visitors other than the man, before putting her phone down, turning on the selfie camera and running towards the sea. As she runs past the man, who is lying on his beach towel facing downwards, she purposely kicks the sand to the manaposs back.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. He quickly turns around and watches her heading to the water and the video cuts to show him packing his belongings and leaving the area. Promise Iaposll make you more uncomfortable than you make me, also my flat feet grip sand as good as a shovel, she added in the caption. After posting the video, the TikToker has been met with mixed responses from viewers. While some praised her braveness, others pointed out that the man didnapost appear to be doing anything other than sunbathing. He was literally minding his own business tanning till she ran right by him and kick sand in his face, one commented, while another added: Didnapost know you own the whole beach  However, others disagreed, with another commenting: He sat right in front of her and you can see him looking at her. She had every right to do what she did! This was so satisfying, thataposs what he deserves. news world-news russian-tank-blown-pieces-single-"Ukraine: Russian tank dramatically destroyed by missileByLee Bullen:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Dramatic footage shows the moment Ukrainian soldiers from the fearsome Azov Regiment blow up a Russian armoured vehicle to pieces in a field. In the video, Ukrainian troops are seen tracking an enemy armoured vehicle as it rolls across a field on the outskirts of the south-eastern coastal city of Mariupol.With a single strike, the vehicle appears to blow up and a large plume of dark smoke fills the air.The footage was shared by the Armed Forces of Ukraine on Friday with the message: Azov in Mariupol continues to destroy the enemy.The regiment has gained a fearsome reputation for wiping out Russian armour.  According to Ukrainian reports, the Azov Regiment destroyed two other Russian tanks on April . The day before, Azov troops destroyed equipment of several Russian units and ammunition depots in the defence of Mariupol. The regiment also claimed to have eliminated many enemy infantry troops. Russian troops invaded Ukraine on February  in what the Kremlin is calling a special military operation. Today marks the th day of the invasion.  From February  to April , the total combat losses of Russian troops stand at an estimated , personnel, according to the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.The Ukrainian military also estimates that Russia has lost  tanks, , armoured combat vehicles,  artillery systems,  MLR systems,  anti-aircraft systems,  aircraft,  helicopters, , vehicles, seven vessels,  fuel tankers,  operational-tactical level UAVs,  units of special equipment and four mobile SRBM systems.The Azov Regiment, formerly known as the Azov Battalion and formally called as the Azov Special Operations Detachment, is a unit of the National Guard of Ukraine - the countryaposs national gendarmerie - and is based in Mariupol.  It is an all-volunteer infantry military unit and has an estimated  members. It has far-right origins and a minority of its members are still said to have far-right tendencies. In latest news, at least  people have been killed and dozens injured after rockets hit a train station in the city of Kramatorsk, in the Donbas region, eastern Ukraine, according to the countryaposs authorities. Donbas is where Russia is believed to be stepping up its offensive as it withdraws from the north of Ukraine. Parts of Donbas have been under pro-Russian separatist occupation since . The so-called Donetsk and Luhansk Peopleaposs Republics were recognised as independent states by Russia just days before the invasion was launched.
